[[AOL]] | released = November 15, 2007 | frequently_updated = yes | discontinued = yes | programming language = C++ (based on [[Mozilla Thunderbird]]) | operating system = [[Cross-platform]] | language = English | genre = [[E-mail client|E-mail]] and [[news client]] | license = | website = http://mailnews.netscape.com/ }} '''Netscape Messenger''' is a standalone, multiplatform [[email client|e-mail]] and [[news client]] that was developed by [[Netscape]]. Announced on June 11, 2007 as ''Netscape Mercury'', the program was intended to accompany the [[web browser]] [[Netscape Navigator 9]], and was based on [[Mozilla]]'s [[Mozilla Thunderbird|Thunderbird]].[http://community.netscape.com/n/pfx/forum.aspx?tsn=1&nav=messages&webtag=ws-nscpbrowser&tid=8688 Netscape Mercury in progress] Retrieved on 2007-06-11 The original name ''Mercury'' was named after the [[Roman mythology|Roman]] god [[Mercury (mythology)|Mercury]], the messenger.[http://community.netscape.com/n/pfx/forum.aspx?msg=8692.4&nav=messages&webtag=ws-nscpbrowser#a4 Feature requests in Mercury] Retrieved on 2007-06-12) It replaced the former [[Netscape Mail & Newsgroups]] client included in versions 4 to 7.2. On November 15, 2007, the alpha was released for [[Linux]], [[Mac OS]], and [[Microsoft Windows]].[http://blog.netscape.com/2007/11/15/netscape-messenger-9-alpha-1-released/ Netscape Blog on Netscape Messenger 9.a] Retrieved on 2007-11-16 On December 28, 2007, Netscape developers announced that AOL would discontinue support for Messenger along with the Navigator browser on February 1, 2008.[http://blog.netscape.com/2007/12/28/end-of-support-for-netscape-web-browsers/ The End of Support for Netscape Web Browsers] - The Netscape Blog AOL later extended support through March 1, 2008. ==Features== Netscape Messenger includes all the features of Mozilla Thunderbird 2.0.0.9, alongside greater [[AOL Instant Messenger|AIM]] integration.
